Award.AwardTitle: Electromagnetic Properties and Hadronic Parity Violation in Lattice QCD
Award.AbstractNarration:
The distributions of charge and magnetism within hadrons will be explored by calculating their magnetic moments and electromagnetic polarizabilities from lattice quantum chromodynamics (QCD). Computations will be performed using background field techniques developed earlier by the PI and collaborators. New techniques will also be developed in conjunction with effective field theory, and computations utilizing lighter quark masses and multiple volumes will be carried out. Manifestations of the weak interaction at low energies will additionally be investigated in lattice QCD. The parity-violating component of non-leptonic weak interactions introduces hadronic parity violation (HPV), and probes the quark-quark correlations deep within hadrons. The precise nature of HPV depends on running the weak interaction down to hadronic scales, and non-perturbative physics that can only be addressed with lattice QCD computations.

This research will help to advance our understanding of particles that make up a nucleus at the most advanced level yet achieved. Members of under-represented groups will be afforded opportunities in nuclear science as a result of this project. Ethnic minority groups constitute a majority of the student population at The City College of New York. In introductory courses serving these students, the PI will integrate nuclear science concepts, focusing on important applications in energy, medicine, and security. In upper-level courses, the PI will integrate numerical work, including examples from this project. Students will gain computational literacy and a broadened understanding of nuclear science concepts. Building on these opportunities at a more professional level, this project will fund the research of a graduate student in nuclear physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant funded research of the principal investigator, Brian C. Tiburzi, for a period of three years, and an additional year via a no-cost extension. Funds were utilized to provide partial support for a post-doctoral research fellow, Jong-Wan Lee. Also included in this funding was financial support for physics doctoral students Steven Vayl and Amol Deshmukh. A number of other research students were mentored by the PI, including an undergraduate student Matthew Matzelle, who also worked on aspects of this project.   

Professor Tiburzi's research focuses on the theory of strong interactions (Quantum Chromodynamics = QCD) , which describes the internal workings of the atomic nucleus. Particles called quarks and gluons are strongly bound inside the protons and neutrons that make up a nucleus. Unraveling the quark and gluon structure of protons and neutrons is notoriously difficult and Tiburzi's work employs state-of-the-art methods in computational physics to solve the theory of strong interactions numerically. This technique, known as Lattice QCD, is a multidisciplinary endeavor which has pushed our knowledge about protons and neutrons to the most advanced level yet. Funding from this project was used to develop new methodology geared toward realistic computations of electromagnetic and parity violating properties of proton, neutrons and light nuclei. This methodology led to theoretical advances in effective quantum field theories and perturbative QCD.

In conjunction with the Nuclear Physics Lattice QCD collaboration (NPLQCD), the PI contributed to several ground-breaking computations as part of this project. The magnetic structure of light nuclei was investigated for the first time from the theory of quarks and gluons (albeit at unphysically large values of the quark masses). This was achieved from Lattice QCD computations through the inclusion of a variable magnetic field. Key results were the first computation of the magnetic moments and magnetic polarizabilities of light nuclei (deuterium, tritium and helium). It was discovered that considerably large magnetic fields can intensify nuclear interactions to the strongest level allowed by unitarity. The simplest nuclear reaction (photo-disintegration of deuterium), furthermore, was explored directly from quark and gluon degrees of freedom. These pioneering developments have opened the door to more realistic computations of few-body nuclear systems from Lattice QCD. 

Contributions of research fellow Jong-Wan Lee helped advance the effective field theory techniques necessary to extract physical parameters from numerical Lattice QCD computations, as well as explored feasibility for the challenging computations necessary to address flavor-symmetry breaking in weak decays of certain QCD bound states. This successful work lead him to accept a further post-doctoral research fellowship at Swansea University in Wales (Fall 2015). The work of undergraduate student Matthew Matzelle considered a special regime of Lattice QCD in which the computational setup can induce QCD to undergo a phase transition. After skillfully solving this problem, he will begin the doctoral program in physics at Northeastern University (Fall 2016).
